Masks make life hell

“As most of us use face masks and rely on eye contact, how will it change the way we communicate?” asks a headline in the Self and Wellbeing section of the Observer Magazine. But even the most expressive, kohl-rimmed, mascara’d eyes cannot convey all that a profoundly deaf or even hard-of-hearing person needs to know, especially in life-or-death circumstances. A physician on TV admitted that when he is in full PPE he cannot hear himself properly, let alone colleagues and patients.

My deaf daughter-in-law is about to give birth. She will need her hearing mother locked in with her for the duration, to interpret medical advice/instructions/explanations in sign language. From a possibly steamy visor, the mum-to-be will be unable to discern congratulations or concern from just the eyes of obstetrician, midwife or mother.

Fun to flirt above a mask? Maybe. Not such fun to flounder in circumstances when masks make lipreading impossible and words unintelligible, and even normal body language is hampered.
Jenny Froude
Beckenham, Kent

“All lives matter – when black lives matter.” That was the chant as it echoed down Baylis Street, the main street of the community I grew up in the heart of Wiradjuri country, Wagga Wagga.

It would have been easy for me to go to Sydney or Melbourne to stand alongside our many thousands of brothers and sisters wanting, demanding, pleading, to see change.

Related: Australian Black Lives Matter protests: tens of thousands demand end to Indigenous deaths in custody

The latest uprising was brought about by devastating scenes that were broadcast across the globe, of the horrific death of George Floyd in the US this week. These scenes touched the very core of Australia’s First Nation people. 

The video hit the depths of empathy for most people across the world, and from social media reactions, the footage touched a nerve with a large number of Australians from all backgrounds.

Social media blew up, #BlackLivesMatter was trending, but many First Nations people of this country ask – and I say this with the utmost empathy and respect to the family, and to George Floyd himself – why does it take a death overseas for people to take the blinkers off in this country?

Of course there were the alt right naysayers, saying mostly on social media to anyone who wanted to listen, “we don’t need that here, thankfully that doesn’t happen in Australia, all lives matter”, highlighting the acts of looting.

The thing is, this does happen in this country. We only had to see the alarming footage of a Sydney youngster just this week be swept off his feet and slammed face-down into the pavement.

I don’t excuse crime and looting, but when a lion is treated poorly and pushed into a corner, it is bound to fight back in its own defence. This lion, people of colour, have been silenced, bashed, battered and bruised for many centuries. I don’t condone violence, but I understand the want to fight back as a response to pain and trauma.

When it comes to the “all lives matter” counter-cries, what many people don’t understand is, no one is saying black lives matter more than white lives. We are saying black lives matter as much as white lives. It’s just that police treatment, historically and current events, prove otherwise.

I knew the story of George Floyd was the same narrative that has been happening here in Australia, not just recently, but since invasions.

I also knew that, if I knew our mob, this incident would spark a traumatic reminder of the lives that have been lost in police custody on this soil.

Talk began to circulate of when and where people would be gathering. 

As I mentioned previously, it would have been easy to head to Sydney or Melbourne, to show support and solidarity with what I knew would be a massive turnout; but I was working in Wagga, the town I grew up in, I knew that Wagga is a hugely progressive town and the people of Wagga were ready. 

We pulled it together in three days. Everyone was on board: local council, local police, local mayor and local MP, and most of the local community.

The town of Wagga and surroundings has a population of approximately 78,000 people with a little over 3,500 First Nations, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, but the growth and inclusivity in the community that I have witnessed personally over the past five or six years has been heart-warming.

A large crowd showed up for the #WaggaSolidarityMarch. Wagga showed up, in big numbers. 

Related: Aboriginal deaths in custody: 434 have died since 1991, new data shows

The chants echoed down a closed off main street: “All lives matter when black lives matter.”

There were speeches and the many, many non-people of colour asking how they can use their privilege to bring about change and equality.

People of Wagga on Saturday turned up, showed support and showed that a large part of the community care, want to listen and continue a conversation. 

Australia, the time has come.

All lives matter, when black lives matter.

• Joe Williams is a proud Wiradjuri man, a motivational speaker, title-winning boxer, dancer and former professional rugby league player

Stimulus programs backing clean energy as a path out of recession would create nearly three times as many jobs for every dollar spent on fossil fuel developments, according to a financial consultancy analysis.

The assessment by professional services firm Ernst & Young (EY) says a government focus on renewable energy and climate-friendly projects to drive the economic recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic could create more than 100,000 direct jobs across the country while cutting greenhouse gas emissions.

Commissioned by environment group the World Wide Fund for Nature, the EY report suggests fast-tracking wind and solar farms that have already been approved, increasing electricity transmission capacity and backing new industries in battery manufacturing, electric buses, renewable hydrogen and manufacturing powered by renewable energy.

Related: Seizing the moment: how Australia can build a green economy from the Covid-19 wreckage

It estimates every $1m spent on renewable energy and exports creates 4.8 full-time jobs in renewable infrastructure or 4.95 jobs in energy efficiency. By comparison, $1m on fossil fuel projects has been found to create 1.7 full-time jobs.

That suggests that if 10% of what the federal and state governments had indicated they would spend in response to Covid-19 was directed towards clean projects it could create 160,000 jobs.

“It represents a fraction of the immediate government stimulus package while generating significant job numbers and reorienting the economy towards a more strategic, low-carbon trajectory,” it says.

It follows a push by the United Nations, banks, investors and financial institutions, and a cross-sector collection of groups representing much of Australian society including business organisations for measures to help recovery from Covid-19 to also address the climate crisis.

While several countries, including the European Union, South Korea and Canada, have backed green recovery measures, an analysis by Bloomberg New Energy Finance found the vast majority of stimulus money so far announced by governments would prop up the fossil fuel economy. The Morrison government has called for a recovery built on gas.

The EY report suggests about 58,000 jobs could be created in construction by clearing the way to accelerate the development of solar and wind farms that had already been planned.

WWF also called for a federal renewables stimulus package of nearly $2bn, including 90% to be spent in the next two years, saying it could generate nearly $10bn of economic benefits. The largest portion, $520m, would be spent on improving energy efficiency and increasing renewable energy in manufacturing, with a goal of Australia becoming a global clean energy manufacturing hub.

Other recommended programs would help create manufacturing industries in batteries and electric buses and cut the cost of solar power for thousands of community organisations. It also recommends further boosting support for renewable hydrogen, which the government and industry have identified as a potential major export industry and local energy source.

Related: Business, unions and green groups call for sustainable Covid-19 recovery with clean energy transition

Nicky Ison, WWF Australia’s energy transition manager, said federal, state and territory governments had an opportunity to rebuild the economy in a way that set it up for prosperity in a world that valued low-carbon goods, in line with the Paris agreement.

She said an energy efficiency drive was a “no regrets” approach as it cut emissions while improving productivity, and an economic rebuild based on renewable energy could re-employ people in industries that had suffered some of the biggest job losses, including construction, manufacturing and professional, scientific and technical services.

“We think that this is a moment. The economy was struggling before the Covid crisis and it is struggling even more now, but a clean stimulus package can address issues holding back renewables and get the ball rolling on more than 100,000 jobs,” she said.

A leaked report by a taskforce advising Australia’s National Covid Coordinating Commission focused on finding ways to lower the cost of gas to help manufacturing recover and did not considers alternatives. Government agencies have found renewable energy is cheaper than fossil fuels. The commission’s chair, Nev Power, later distanced himself from the recommendations in the leaked report but backed gas as central to the recovery.

An assessment by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, commissioned at the Paris summit by all signatories including Australia, found limiting global heating to 1.5C above pre-industrial levels was likely to require the world reaching net zero emissions by 2050. The Morrison government has not set this target for Australia.

Scientific analyses have found under current policies the world is currently headed for more than 3C of warming, an increase scientists have warned would lead to significant ecological collapse.
